story.description: We currently use Delayed::Job for polling CI systems. This is a poor design. IO bound polling is not well suited for a threading framework, especially one with a very small set of available threads. Typically this means that if ~3 projects take a long time to poll, the system gets backlogged (Delayed::Job is set to only use 3 jobs). It also means that the project needs 4 connections to the database at any one time, and only for an almost instantaneous update. We could increase the number of jobs available but this can cause quite a large increase in memory usage and will likely hit DB limits on hosts like Heroku. We should change this to use the reactor pattern, it is very performant for this type of usage. Two possible candidates for this in Ruby land are Typheous or Eventmachine. Typheous[https://rubygems.org/gems/typhoeus] looks the most simple of the two, but it doesn't look like it allows ad hoc queuing of requests once you're in its event loop. Eventmachine[https://rubygems.org/gems/eventmachine] looks like the more capable solution, but looks a little more complex and involved. Neither of these unfortunately do HTTP client requests quite as well as say restclient or httpclient, so we'll possibly need to package certificates and handle authentication a little more explicitly (We had to remove httpclient recently so this is a bit of a moot point).
story.name: Improve polling efficiency

story.description: The parsing modules are quite badly designed and exhibit the following problems: 1. There are multiple points of failure, scattered throughout the code 2. Invalid payloads can sometimes be treated as valid ones, but produce unexpected results 3. Parsing is complex and difficult to understand 4. The modules for parsing are named after their implementation instead of their purpose 5. They rescue exceptions not related to parsing, which could hide faults in the parser 6. Treating a project as offline because we couldn't parse it is misleading 7. Payloads are not treated atomically, if we can parse part of a payload we could still get changes. If we can't trust part of a payload we should not trust ALL of it. 8. We don't log many kinds of parser failures so often can't diagnose problems 9. None of the parsers have unit tests Our parsing requirements are not complex, this design can be drastically simplified without a great deal of work.
story.name: Refactor parsing

story.description: We've been rethinking this problem. Essentially the reasons parsing would fail are: 1. Corrupted transmission. Incredibly unlikely we are after all using TCP transmission. 2. Bad / garbage data. Highly unlikely, could be caused by broken CI implementation - we should definitely fail and log if this happens. 3. The payload format has changed or been encoded differently and we can no longer parse it properly. Definitely fail and log. So it seems we shouldn't just fail silently, we should at the very least log an error to improve visibility and speed a resolution.
story.name: If a project payload fails to parse there is no record of the error
